title-group.article-title: Exposure of the Medial Talar Dome
title-group.subtitle: Bi-Plane Chevron Medial Malleolus Osteotomy

abstract.p: Open surgical exposure of the medial aspect of the talus is primarily indicated for osteochondral lesions of the talus and talar body fractures. Secondary to the difficulty of access, a variety of techniques have been described. The surgical techniques described in the literature include transmalleolar access windows, medial and anterior tibial osteotomies, and resection osteotomies (plafondoplasty). The purpose of this article is to describe the surgical technique for the bi-planar chevron osteotomy of the medial malleolus. This osteotomy can provide full exposure to the entire medial aspect of the talus. The orientation of the osteotomy allows for perpendicular placement of instrumentation on the medial half of the talus and is particularly useful for cartilage transplant procedures. The technique is reproducible and has a low complication rate when performed correctly.

disp-quote.p: “Osteotomies of the malleoli are performed primarily for exposure and treatment of osteochondral lesions of the talus.”

body.p: Osteotomies of the malleoli are performed primarily for exposure and treatment of osteochondral lesions of the talus (OLT) and for reduction and fixation of talar body fractures. A variety of techniques have been described in the literature.1-9 The bi-plane chevron medial malleolar osteotomy technique allows for excellent visualization of the entire medial aspect of the talus, is relatively simple to perform, and has a low complication rate when done correctly.

sec.title: Surgical Anatomy
sec.p: The medial malleolus is bordered anteriorly by the saphenous nerve and vein and posteriorly by the posterior tibial tendon. The distal fragment of the osteotomy is reflected over the deltoid ligament.

sec.title: Technique
sec.p: This surgical technique may be performed in an outpatient or hospital setting under general anesthesia, preferably with a peripheral nerve block. Patients are placed in the supine position with a well-padded thigh tourniquet. A bump can be placed under the contralateral hip to increase external rotation if needed. The foot and leg are prepped and draped, an esmarch is used to exsanguinate the operative leg, and the tourniquet is insufflated.

A direct medial approach to the medial malleolous is performed with a curvilinear skin incision (Figure 1). Anterior and posterior skin flaps are developed, leaving the periosteum of the tibia intact. The posterior skin flap is developed to the posterior tibial tendon. A small incision is made over the periosteum and tendon sheath and a Homan retractor is inserted to protect the tendon. The anterior skin flap is developed to the anteromedial joint line. A retractor is placed into the anteromedial ankle joint to retract the soft tissues and provide orientation to the joint line (Figure 2).

caption.p: Curvilinear skin incision for direct medial approach to the medial malleolus.
Soft tissue dissection and isolation of the medial malleolus. Posterior retractor is placed to protect the posterior tibial tendon. Anterior retractor is placed in the anteromedial joint.

sec.p: A chevron incision, apex proximal, is made in the periosteum at the same orientation as the planned osteotomy. The lateral extension into the joint is determined by the orientation of the base of the osteotomy. The anterior arthrotomy, with a view of the osteochondral lesion, is useful to guide the trajectory of the osteotomy.
Guide wires for the cannulated screws are inserted across the anticipated osteotomy site, drilled, and tapped before the osteotomy is made (Figure 3).

caption.p: Preparing for the osteotomy. A chevron incision is made in the periosteum of the medial malleolus. Guide wires are placed into the medial malleolus and over drilled before the osteotomy is made.

sec.p: A sagittal saw is used to initiate the osteotomy with the apex of the inverted V proximal in the midline of the medial distal tibia. The obliquity of the saw blade can be modified to allow for larger or smaller exposures of the medial talus (Figure 4). The cut is made with the saw until cortical resistance is felt and then stop. The osteotomy is completed with an osteotome, to purposefully create greater interdigitation of the osteotomy fragments. The distal fragment is mobilized inferiorly over the deltoid ligament. Distraction is achieved with a Hintermann retractor, revealing the entire dome of the talus and allowing for perpendicular access to the medial half of the talus (Figure 5).

caption.p: Sagittal saw blade placement for the osteotomy. Oblique orientation of the saw blade can be changed to increase or decrease exposure of the talus. Saw blade is used to complete 80% to 90% of the osteotomy. Final completion of the osteotomy is performed with ostetomes.
Exposure of the talus. Distal fragment is rotated distal on the deltoid ligament. Distraction can be achieved with a Hintermann retractor.

sec.p: Manipulation of the osteochondral lesion is achieved through the osteotomy. If enhanced vertical access is required for osteochondral plug transfer, the proximal portion of the V cut can be plastically deformed without disruption of the oblique arms.

To repair the osteotomy, the distal fragment is rotated back into place. The previously drilled guide wires are placed in their original orientation. The saw blade can be placed back into the osteotomy site before the screws are inserted. This helps align the proximal and distal predrilled holes and prevent over reduction of the osteotomy through the kurf of the saw blade. Two screws are then placed for fixation (Figures 6 and 7). This fixation can be augmented with a medial antiglide plate for larger osteotomies or in patients at risk for noncompliance with postoperative weight bearing restrictions.

Absorbable suture is used to repair the periosteum over the osteotomy site. Deep and subcutaneous layers are closed in a similar fashion, followed by nonabsorbable horizontal mattress closure for the skin. Patients are then placed in a bulky soft dressing and well-padded AO splint.

caption.p: Immediate postoperative x-ray of osteotomy and fixation.

sec.title: Postoperative Management
sec.p: All patients are non–weight bearing for a minimum of 6 weeks, depending on the indications for the procedure. A typical postoperative course includes conversion to a non–weight bearing cast and suture removal at 10 to 14 days after surgery. Radiographs are taken at 2-week intervals to monitor alignment and healing. At 4 weeks patients are transitioned to a bootwalker to begin non–weight bearing range of motion exercises. At 6 weeks, patients transition to weight bearing to tolerance with the commencement of physical therapy. Physical therapy and rehabilitation protocols are dictated by the primary diagnosis (eg, OLT).

sec.title: Results and Complications
sec.p: A retrospective case series of 28 patients who underwent a bi-plane chevron of the medial malleolus was reviewed at our institution. There were 14 male and 14 female patients with an average age of 33 years (range = 15-65, SD = 13.67). The average follow-up was 38 months (range = 4-76 months). Twenty-six of the osteotomies were performed for osteochondral dessicans lesions (OCDs) of the talus and 2 osteotomies were for talar fractures. The average time to clinical healing based on chart review was 10.14 weeks (range = 5-34 weeks). The average time to heal based on radiographic review was 10.46 weeks (range = 4-32 weeks, SD = 5.37). One patient required hardware removal due to pain. There were no postoperative infections, there was 1 delayed union (34 weeks to complete clinical and radiographic healing), and there were no nonunions requiring revision surgery.

sec.title: Summary
sec.p: The bi-plane chevron osteotomy of the medial malleolus is a reproducible surgical technique that allows for excellent exposure of the talar dome. This approach is particularly useful for addressing large posterior and medial OLTs, allowing for perpendicular exposure to the medial half of the talus.
